Congratulations to Board of Education Parliamentarian Bob Friend on being named Lombard’s 2020 Man of the Year by the Rotary Club of Lombard. Friend was recognized during a ceremony at Lilacia Park on Sept. 9. Also, congratulations to Brigitte O’Brien on being named Lombard’s 2020 Woman of the Year. The Man of the Year and Woman of the Year program recognizes people in the community who make Lombard a wonderful place to live and work.

Friend was recognized for his service on our Board of Education and his involvement on the Tri-Town YMCA Board of Directors. He is a member of the Lombard Area Chamber of Commerce and the Men’s Club at First United Methodist Church of Lombard, where he most recently served on the Health and Safety Committee. He is a former member of the Lombard School District 44 Board of Education.

O’Brien is a member of Kiwanis Club of Lombard and is the club liaison to Glenbard East’s Key Club. She also is vice chairman of the Lombard Historic Preservation Commission and a member of the Lombard Historical Society.

Congratulations to Glenbard East student Sam Greetis and Glenbard South students Luke Aliga and Gabrielle Michael on their selection to the National Association for Music Education (NAfME) All-National Music Honor Ensembles. They were eligible to audition based on their selection this past year in the Illinois Music Education Association All-State Music Ensembles and joined students from across the country in submitting an extensive recorded audition.

Greetis was selected for the All National Honor Band on trumpet. He was selected for this honor last year as well, making him the first two-time national musician in Glenbard history. Aliga was selected for the All-National Honor Band on piccolo, and Michael was selected for the All-National Honor Orchestra on French horn.

Glenbard East students Gabrielle Spontak, Megan High, Ashley Ziemer, Grace Iovinelli, and Kaitlin Kalsen recently attended a weeklong program at the Marine Biological Laboratory of the University of Chicago in Woods Hole, MA. This facility is one of the largest & oldest marine research sites and does some of the most important research and breeding programs in the world.

Our students worked with Dr. Nipam Patel, an award-winning microbiologist and researcher in embryological development and structural color. They investigated many areas in marine biology, including anatomy and physiology of marine vertebrates and invertebrates, anesthetizing fish, the care and breeding of octopus and squid and analyzing embryo development using antibody staining and a Confocal Microscope to visualize developmental staging. Wow, what a week! #GlenbardPride
